comments.raw_text:
The first block was from the migration script which simply populated the field and then added an activity log entry for the change. That is going to be in any emails sent about a bug change for any affected bugs (just the first notification). 

The second block looks like the user was just adding themselves to CC list and somehow Bugzilla thought there was a slight change to the crash signature value even though it looks to be the same. Maybe the textarea formatted it differently in the user's browser?

dkl
comments.author: dkl@mozilla.com

comments.text:
(In reply to comment #4)
> (In reply to comment #3)
> > Not sure what you're asking me ... but I didn't intentionally change the crash
> > signature field.
> 
> That makes me think this is a bug in bugzilla one way or another.

Yeah I was not implying that Kyle intentionally changed the crash signature. I have seen in the past where a browser can alter the way form data is displayed unknowingly to the user in some way that would make Bugzilla think it has changed. If you look at the change log entry, the text is essentially the same except for a new line that has been added to the updated value somehow. So the process would be to see if it can be reproduced somehow and see what combination of browser/version/configuration that may have caused it.

dkl
comments.author: dkl@mozilla.com
comments.creator: dkl@mozilla.com

comments.text: It doesn't look like that linebreak was actually added to the field in the bug, though.
comments.author: kairo@kairo.at
comments.creator: kairo@kairo.at
comments.raw_text: It doesn't look like that linebreak was actually added to the field in the bug, though.

I think you're referring to the problem of browsers trying to restore form control values when you go back to a page, for example.  That would only lead to mid-air collisions as far as I know.  Otherwise the browser would not modify the value of a textarea element if it's not modified by user or script.
comments.author: ehsan.akhgari@gmail.com
comments.text: I think you're referring to the problem of browsers trying to restore form control values when you go back to a page, for example.  That would only lead to mid-air collisions as far as I know.  Otherwise the browser would not modify the value of a textarea element if it's not modified by user or script.
comments.creator: ehsan.akhgari@gmail.com

(In reply to comment #8)
> Here's another example without a newline:

there's nothing wrong with that email; the first table is because there was a pending email (from the migration script), which is sent with the next change to the bug.  notice the changer for the first table is 'nobody'.

the second table is also fine, there isn't an entry for 'Crash Signature'.
